acme-resource-certificate.body:
resource "acme_certificate" "$1" {
    # dns_challenge - (Required) - The [DNS challenge](#using-dns-challenges) to use
    dns_challenge = ""

    # account_key_pem - (Required) - The private key of the account that is
    account_key_pem = ""

    # common_name - (Optional) The certificate's common name, the primary domain that the
    common_name = ""

    # subject_alternative_names - (Optional) The certificate's subject alternative names,
    subject_alternative_names = ""

    # key_type - (Optional) The key type for the certificate's private key. Can be one of:
    key_type = ""

    # certificate_request_pem - (Optional) A pre-created certificate request, such as one
    certificate_request_pem = ""

    # key_type - (Optional) `key_type`, and optionally `subject_alternative_names`) need to be specified.
    key_type = ""

    # must_staple - (Optional) Enables the [OCSP Stapling Required][ocsp-stapling]
    must_staple = ""

    # min_days_remaining - (Optional) - The minimum amount of days remaining on the
    min_days_remaining = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
acme-resource-certificate.description:
The `acme_certificate` resource can be used to create and manage an ACME TLS
certificate. -> **NOTE:** As the usage model of Terraform generally sees it as being run on
a different server than a certificate would normally be placed on, the
`acme_certifiate` resource only supports DNS challenges.

acme-resource-registration.body:
resource "acme_registration" "$1" {
    # email_address - (Required) - The contact email address for the account.
    email_address = ""

    # account_key_pem - (Required) - The private key used to identity the account.
    account_key_pem = ""

    # Exported Attributes
}
acme-resource-registration.description:
The `acme_registration` resource can be used to create and manage accounts on an
ACME server. Once registered, the same private key that has been used for
registration can be used to request authorizations for certificates. -> This resource is named `acme_registration` for historical reasons - in the
ACME v1 spec, a _registration_ referred to the account entity.  This resource
name is stable and more than likely will not change until a later major version
of the provider, if at all.
